text:
In today’s world, almost everyone owns a cell phone, and many of us use them constantly to text friends, check directions, or scroll through social media. Because phones play such a huge role in our daily lives, some people argue that drivers should be allowed to use them while on the road. However, even though phones can be helpful, I strongly believe that drivers should not be able to use cell phones in any capacity while operating a vehicle. Cell phones cause distraction, increase the chances of accidents, and put everyone’s safety at risk.

To begin with, cell phones are one of the biggest sources of distraction for drivers. Even a quick glance at a text message takes the driver’s eyes off the road for several seconds. During that time, the car is still moving, and anything could happen—a pedestrian might cross the street, the car in front might stop suddenly, or an obstacle could appear. When a driver’s attention is divided, they are much slower to react, which can easily lead to dangerous situations. Driving demands full concentration, and a cell phone simply gets in the way.

In addition, using a phone while driving greatly increases the risk of accidents. Studies have shown that texting or even talking on the phone while behind the wheel slows reaction time almost as much as driving under the influence of alcohol. This means that a driver using a phone is more likely to miss important signals, drift out of their lane, or fail to brake in time. It only takes one mistake to cause a serious crash. The consequences can affect not only the driver but also passengers, other vehicles, cyclists, and pedestrians.

Some people argue that hands-free devices or voice commands make phone use safe. While these tools may reduce the need to touch the phone, they do not eliminate distraction. The driver’s mind is still focused on the conversation or task instead of the road. Mental distraction can be just as dangerous as physical distraction, and in a moving vehicle, even a moment of confusion or inattention can lead to harm. No piece of technology can replace a driver’s responsibility to stay alert.

Finally, banning cell phone use while driving helps create safer roads for everyone. When drivers dedicate their full focus to driving, they make better decisions and reduce the chances of accidents. Laws against using phones behind the wheel send a clear message: safety comes first. If people need to check their phone, they can pull over, park, and look at it safely without risking lives.

In conclusion, drivers should not be allowed to use cell phones in any way while operating a vehicle. The distraction they create, the increased likelihood of accidents, and the danger they pose to everyone on the road outweigh any convenience they might offer. As cell phones become more common, it is even more important to make responsible choices. After all, no text message or notification is worth someone’s life.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Today the majority of humans own and operate cell phones on a daily basis. In essay form, explain if drivers should or should not be able to use cell phones in any capacity while operating a vehicle."

text:
Cell phones have become such a normal part of our lives that it’s hard to imagine a day without them. We use them for everything—from texting friends to checking the weather to listening to music. But even though cell phones are useful, drivers should not be allowed to use them while operating a vehicle. Using a phone while driving puts everyone at risk, reduces focus, and causes accidents that could easily be avoided.

To begin with, using a cell phone while driving puts everyone on the road in danger. When a driver glances at their phone, they take their eyes off the road, even if it’s just for a moment. A lot can happen in that moment. A child could run into the street, a car could suddenly stop, or a traffic light could change. If a driver is staring at a screen, they might not notice in time. It only takes one bad decision to cause a serious crash.

Another important reason is that cell phones take the driver’s focus away from what matters most: paying attention. Even if someone thinks they can multitask, the human brain is not great at doing two important things at once. A driver talking on the phone—even through Bluetooth—is still distracted. Their mind is focused on the conversation instead of the road. This means slower reaction times and worse decision-making, which are both dangerous while driving.

Finally, accidents caused by cell phone use are completely avoidable. Unlike weather conditions or traffic jams, phone distractions are something drivers can control. All they have to do is put the phone away until they reach their destination. Many phones even have “Do Not Disturb While Driving” modes built in. If someone really needs to make a call or send a message, they can pull over safely and do it without putting other people at risk.

In conclusion, drivers should not be allowed to use cell phones in any way while operating a vehicle. With how dangerous and distracting cell phones can be behind the wheel, it simply isn’t worth the risk. If we want safer roads, fewer accidents, and more responsible drivers, then keeping phones out of drivers’ hands is the best decision.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Today the majority of humans own and operate cell phones on a daily basis. In essay form, explain if drivers should or should not be able to use cell phones in any capacity while operating a vehicle."

text:
Every day, people depend on their cell phones for information, entertainment, and communication. But no matter how important a message or notification seems, drivers should not be allowed to use cell phones while operating a vehicle. Driving while using a phone is unsafe, irresponsible, and risks the lives of both the driver and everyone around them.

First, using a phone while driving is unsafe because it takes the driver’s focus away from the road. Even a quick glance at a text message can mean missing a red light, drifting out of a lane, or failing to notice someone in a crosswalk. Cars move fast, and accidents can happen in seconds. When a driver’s eyes are on their phone instead of the road, that time is enough for disaster.

Second, cell phone use is irresponsible when behind the wheel. A driver has one main job: to get themselves and others to their destination safely. If someone chooses to text or scroll through apps while driving, they are choosing convenience over responsibility. This decision doesn’t just affect them—it affects everyone sharing the road.

Finally, cell-phone-related accidents are entirely preventable. Drivers can turn off their phones, use “Do Not Disturb” mode, or wait until they arrive before checking notifications. These simple choices prevent unnecessary injuries and deaths. If we already have the tools to avoid danger, why ignore them?

In the end, safety must come before screens. Drivers should not be allowed to use cell phones while operating a vehicle because the risk is simply too high. Choosing safety protects everyone—not just the person holding the phone.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Today the majority of humans own and operate cell phones on a daily basis. In essay form, explain if drivers should or should not be able to use cell phones in any capacity while operating a vehicle."

text:
Cell phones are helpful tools, but they can become extremely dangerous when used in the wrong situation. One of the most dangerous times to use a cell phone is while driving. For that reason, drivers should not be permitted to use cell phones in any capacity when operating a vehicle. Phone use causes distractions, slows reaction time, and leads to accidents that could easily be stopped.

To begin, cell phones distract drivers visually, physically, and mentally. Looking at a screen means taking your eyes off the road. Holding a phone means taking at least one hand off the wheel. Thinking about a conversation or text message means your brain isn’t fully focused on driving. With so many distractions happening at once, a driver becomes less capable of reacting to sudden dangers.

Also, reaction time decreases dramatically when a driver uses a phone. When someone is reading a message or talking on the phone, their attention is divided. This means they respond more slowly to changes in traffic, like a car stopping suddenly or a pedestrian entering a crosswalk. A delay of even half a second can be the difference between avoiding a crash and causing one.

Most importantly, accidents caused by cell phones are 100% preventable. Unlike bad weather or mechanical problems, using a phone while driving is a choice. Drivers can choose to ignore their phones until they are safely parked. Making this choice would save lives.

For these reasons, drivers should not be allowed to use cell phones while driving. The dangers of distraction are too serious, and preventing accidents should always come first.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Today the majority of humans own and operate cell phones on a daily basis. In essay form, explain if drivers should or should not be able to use cell phones in any capacity while operating a vehicle."

text:
We live in a world where communication is constant. Phones buzz with messages, notifications, and calls all day long. But when someone is behind the wheel, those notifications should not be a priority. Drivers should not be allowed to use cell phones while operating a vehicle because doing so puts lives at risk, causes unnecessary accidents, and has safer alternatives.

First, cell phone use while driving threatens everyone’s safety. A driver needs to watch the road, check mirrors, and make quick decisions. When they look down at a phone, they lose awareness of what is happening around them. Even a short distraction can lead to a collision.

Second, many accidents today are caused by distracted driving, especially due to phone use. These accidents injure thousands of people each year and damage property. What makes this even more tragic is that these accidents didn’t have to happen. They were caused by someone choosing to look at their phone instead of focusing on driving.

Finally, safer alternatives already exist. Drivers can pull over, use hands-free navigation, or wait to check their messages until the car is parked. None of these options put people in danger. If we have a safer choice, we should take it.

In conclusion, no call, text, or notification is worth a life. The road should get a driver’s full attention, and cell phones make that impossible. That’s why drivers should not be allowed to use cell phones while operating a vehicle

text:
During summer break, students finally get time to relax, explore interests, and learn in their own ways. Because of this, summer projects should be student-designed instead of teacher-designed. When students create their own projects, they are more motivated, more creative, and more likely to learn something meaningful.

First, student-designed projects increase motivation. When students choose what they want to study, they actually care about the project. For example, a student who loves cars could design a project exploring how engines work, while someone who enjoys writing could create a short story collection. Students are more excited when they work on something they choose themselves.

Second, student-designed projects encourage creativity and independence. Instead of following strict instructions, students have the chance to plan, research, and make decisions on their own. This helps them build real-life skills like time management and problem-solving. These skills are just as important as academic knowledge.

Finally, student-designed projects lead to more meaningful learning. If a student chooses to research transportation systems in different cities, they will likely remember what they learned because it mattered to them personally. In contrast, teacher-designed projects can sometimes feel repetitive or boring.

In conclusion, summer projects should be student-designed. They motivate students, allow creativity, and create deeper learning experiences. When students have ownership over their project, they learn more and enjoy the process.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Some schools require students to complete summer projects to assure they continue learning during their break. Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples. "

text:
While student-designed projects sound fun, teacher-designed summer projects are more effective for real learning. Teachers know what students need to practice, they can create fair assignments for everyone, and they can make sure the project connects to the curriculum.

First, teachers understand what skills students struggle with. A student might choose something too easy or unrelated to learning goals. But teachers can design projects that strengthen reading, writing, math, or research skills. For example, a history teacher might assign a short essay about an important historical event to make sure students keep practicing writing.

Second, teacher-designed projects are fair and equal. If every student designs their own project, some might choose something simple while others choose something very challenging. Teacher-created assignments make sure everyone is graded fairly on the same expectations.

Finally, teacher-designed projects ensure the work connects to the upcoming school year. A science teacher might assign a small lab experiment to prepare students for the next science unit. This helps prevent students from forgetting important information over the summer.

Overall, teacher-designed projects guarantee that all students learn the right material, get fair assignments, and stay ready for the next grade. For these reasons, teacher-designed projects are the better option.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Some schools require students to complete summer projects to assure they continue learning during their break. Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples. "

text:
The debate about summer projects usually comes down to teacher-designed vs. student-designed. But the best solution is a combination of both. Teachers should provide a general structure, but students should be able to customize the project based on their interests.

First, a mixed approach keeps learning meaningful. Teachers can choose the main subject—like science, history, or math—while students choose the specific topic. For example, in a science project, one student might study electric cars while another studies ocean animals. This keeps the project educational but still interesting.

Second, this approach helps teachers maintain fairness. Since everyone follows the same basic guidelines and expectations, grading becomes easier and more equal. However, students still have freedom to explore what they enjoy.

Finally, mixing both styles builds strong academic and creative skills. Students learn responsibility and independence by choosing their topic, but they also practice important school skills because the teacher provides structure.

In the end, the best summer projects come from teamwork between students and teachers. With both voices involved, learning becomes fun, fair, and flexible.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Some schools require students to complete summer projects to assure they continue learning during their break. Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples. "

text:
Summer projects shouldn’t just be about memorizing facts. They should teach students real-world skills they can use in the future. This is why summer projects should be student-designed. When students create their own projects, they learn how to plan, research, and think independently.

First, student-designed projects help students learn how to manage their time. For example, if a student chooses to build a small model of a transportation system, they must decide how long each step will take and create their own deadlines. These are skills adults use in jobs every day.

Second, student-designed projects encourage self-motivation. Instead of simply doing what the teacher tells them, students must take initiative. They choose their topic, gather materials, and stay responsible throughout the process. This builds confidence and independence.

Lastly, student-designed projects let students explore personal interests and possible future careers. A student interested in engineering might design a project about how cars move or how bridges are built. This could inspire them to pursue that field later in life.

For these reasons, student-designed projects are the best choice. They help students grow not only academically but also as responsible, independent thinkers.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Some schools require students to complete summer projects to assure they continue learning during their break. Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples. "

text:
Although student choice is important, teacher-designed summer projects make sure students don’t fall behind during the long break. Without guidance, some students might choose projects that are too easy or skip work altogether. Teacher-designed assignments help prevent learning gaps and keep everyone on track.

First, teacher-designed projects target essential skills that students need to review. Teachers know which topics students often forget by September, like math facts or reading comprehension. Assigning a project that reviews these skills helps students stay sharp.

Second, teacher-designed projects provide structure that some students need. During summer, it's easy to get distracted by vacations or hobbies. A clearly planned project gives students a schedule and a purpose, making them more likely to complete the work.

Finally, these projects keep the entire class working at the same level. When school starts again, teachers won’t have to reteach as much material because students stayed academically active.

In conclusion, teacher-designed projects prevent learning gaps, give structure, and help students enter the new school year with confidence. Even though student-designed projects can be creative, teacher-designed ones ensure every student stays prepared.

Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples. "

text:
I agree that all students should participate in at least one extracurricular activity. Just like a car needs fuel to keep moving, students need activities outside the classroom to help them grow. Clubs, sports, and other groups give students energy and skills that regular classes don’t always provide.

First, extracurricular activities help students learn teamwork, just like people working together on a busy highway. For example, being on a sports team teaches cooperation the same way drivers must cooperate by following road rules. When students work together, they learn how to communicate, solve problems, and respect others.

Second, activities help students discover their interests. Think of it like trying different types of transportation—you won’t know if you prefer biking, driving, or taking the bus unless you try them. Likewise, students might try art club, robotics, or the yearbook staff and find something they love.

Finally, these activities prepare students for the future. A student who joins the automotive club might learn how engines work, which could lead to a job in car design or mechanics. Extracurriculars give students a “test drive” of different careers.

For all these reasons, I agree with the principal. Activities keep students moving forward—just like fuel keeps a car on the road.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Your principal has decided that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. For example, students could participate in sports, work on the yearbook, or serve on the student council. Do you agree or disagree with this decision? Use specific details and examples to convince others to support your position. "

text:
I disagree with requiring students to join an extracurricular activity. Forcing every student to join a club is like forcing everyone to drive the same type of car. People have different needs, responsibilities, and comfort levels, and one rule can’t fit everyone.

First, some students already have “full schedules,” just like highways during rush hour. They may have jobs, family responsibilities, or long commutes. Forcing them to add an activity is like adding more traffic to an already crowded road—it only causes stress.

Second, not everyone learns best in group environments. Some people prefer quiet time, the same way some travelers prefer walking instead of driving. Forcing them into social activities may make them uncomfortable or anxious.

Finally, students should have the freedom to choose how they spend their time. If someone uses their free time to work on personal hobbies—like building model cars or designing imaginary transportation systems—that can be just as educational as joining a school club.

In conclusion, requiring extracurricular activities is not fair to everyone. Just like transportation, students need choices that match their lives.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Your principal has decided that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. For example, students could participate in sports, work on the yearbook, or serve on the student council. Do you agree or disagree with this decision? Use specific details and examples to convince others to support your position. "

text:
I agree with the principal’s decision because extracurricular activities help keep students on the right track—just like train rails keep trains moving safely and efficiently.

First, activities give students structure. A student on the track team or student council learns how to manage time and responsibilities. It’s like planning a bus route: without a schedule, everything becomes chaotic.

Second, activities prevent students from wasting time. If students stay after school to participate in something meaningful, they are less likely to get into trouble. It’s similar to how cities build bike lanes to give people safe, healthy ways to travel.

Third, participating in activities helps students build skills they’ll need later in life. For example, joining a transportation or engineering club might inspire someone to become a city planner or car designer. Activities give students the tools to travel toward their goals.

For these reasons, having at least one extracurricular activity helps students stay focused, involved, and moving in a positive direction.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Your principal has decided that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. For example, students could participate in sports, work on the yearbook, or serve on the student council. Do you agree or disagree with this decision? Use specific details and examples to convince others to support your position. "

text:
I disagree with requiring every student to participate in an extracurricular activity. Students should choose what path they want to take, just like drivers choose which road to follow. One rule for everyone is too limiting.

First, some students enjoy using their free time for personal projects. For example, a student who loves cars might spend their afternoons restoring an old engine or designing futuristic vehicles. These activities are just as educational as school clubs but happen outside of school.

Second, forcing students into activities can make them feel trapped, like being stuck in a traffic jam. When people are pressured into something they don’t like, they won’t enjoy it or learn much from it.

Finally, not all students have transportation to stay after school. Some rely on buses, or their parents work late. Requiring them to join a club could create problems with getting home safely.

Because every student’s situation is different, they should be allowed to choose their own route instead of being forced into one lane.
prompt: Write an argumentive essay about cars and transportation, in the style of a 6th-12th grader with the following essay prompt: "Your principal has decided that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. For example, students could participate in sports, work on the yearbook, or serve on the student council. Do you agree or disagree with this decision? Use specific details and examples to convince others to support your position. "

text:
I believe the best solution is not to force all students to participate in activities, but to encourage them strongly while offering flexible options. In transportation, the best systems give people choices—cars, buses, bikes, trains—so everyone can find what works for them. Schools should be the same.

First, activities help students develop new skills, so it’s good to guide them toward joining. But instead of requiring it, teachers could help students find clubs related to their interests, such as a transportation engineering club, a car mechanics workshop, or an environmental group focused on reducing traffic pollution.

Second, schools could offer activities during school hours, like advisory periods or enrichment classes. This removes the transportation problem of staying late or needing rides.

Finally, giving students choices keeps them motivated. If someone wants to join robotics because they enjoy building vehicles or machines, they should. If someone prefers art, music, or writing about cars and travel, that's great too.

With a flexible system—just like a well-planned transit network—students can find activities that truly fit them.
